While it’s tempting to answer this question with a) funny examples of time travel derived from fiction or b) philosophical thoughts on the possibility or impossibility of time travel, for the sake of taking the question seriously and framing an answer in the context of Quora’s best traditions. Firstly, instead of simply replying ‘no’, it’s important to explain why the answer is supposed to be ‘no’. And here we have to start with some assumptions. Because I’m not a physicist, neither will most of Quora’s audience be, I shall attempt to make things simple. Secondly, where comes the whole idea of time travel being ‘possible’, in the physical — not fictional — sense of the word? Well, basically we have to understand that Einstein’s relativity equations are not only a description of our current universe, but they are rather a set of complex equations with multiple solutions, and each solution describes a particular universe. By filling in certain assumptions and variables in Einstein’s equations, we can come up with the description of a universe, and we can check with the observations of our own universe and thus see if we have found the ‘right’ solution to the equation. Several people (including Einstein) have proposed many solutions and agreed upon those that better describe our universe. Nevertheless, finding out other solutions can possibly throw some light in particularly difficult questions about our universe, which might be very hard to solve using the ‘correct’ equations for our universe, but very simple when considering solutions for other universes. This might sound strange until we understand that in the hard sciences this approach is very common: to solve a complex problem in one domain, scientists try to figure out a way to represent that domain in a way where the complex problem becomes quite simple, solve it, and then spend the rest of the academic paper explaining how the two domains are related. A very simple example: we can assume that Earth’s orbit around the Sun is a circle and not an ellipse, and therefore make much easier calculations — like saying, for example, when the seasons are supposed to start: it’s easy to figure out how to divide a circle in four sections, each comprised of 90 degrees of arc, which, in turn, makes calculations rather simple. Now we know that Earth’s orbit is an ellipse with the Sun in one of the focus, but the difference is not that great, so that we can do some basic calculations and assumptions using the orbit as a circle, just to reach some conclusions very quickly; and, later, we can explain things in more detail, by making the same calculations using elliptical equations. The point is that we can advance very quickly and come to interesting conclusions using a simple model; if we can see how our theory applies to that model, then we can argue that it is sufficiently similar to the ‘real’ model, and do the much harder calculations at a later stage. There are, indeed, some solutions to Einstein’s equations that create so-called ‘closed timelike curves’ — paths across spacetime where, indeed, time travel is possible. One of such solutions was shown by the infamous Gödel[1], a horrible little Austrian-American mathematician and philosopher who made life hard for everyone by shattering their glorious dreams. Bertrand Russell’s Principia Mathematica would have been the greatest mathematical accomplishment of the 20th century, and Russell credited as the greatest mathematician ever, if annoying Gödel hadn’t proven that Russell was wrong, using one of Gödel’s infamous Incompleteness Theorems, which have plagued both mathematicians and philosophers ever since — because it proves that it’s impossible to describe this universe completely merely with mathematical formalisms, contrary to what we have always learned at school. Scientists, mathematicians, and philosophers have been trying to prove Gödel wrong (they all failed) or that his theorems didn’t apply to [insert area of knowledge here] (they have had better success in this area). As you can see from my sarcasm, I personally think that Gödel was the best mathematician of the 20th century, but because he annoyed everyone else by disproving their theories, and, to make matters worse, left a mathematical ‘proof’ of God’s existence written allegedly on his deathbed, everybody universally hates him and tries to strike his accomplishments out of the history of science. Well, almost. One of such accomplishments was, indeed, showing that Einstein’s relativity could be used to mathematically describe an universe where time travel was possible and legitimate (note: to be honest, he just validated an earlier formulation by a fellow mathematician; but as he was a regular correspondent with Einstein and generally annoyed everybody else and was therefore well-known — especially because his work tends to have annoyingly difficult arguments to disprove). Now this has some intriguing consequences, and, of course, the first question to be raised is if Gödel’s solution could apply to our own universe as well. In general, the answer ought to be ‘no’, since the so-called ‘Gödel universe’ lacks some vital characteristics that are present in our own universe. However, this is not the point; because Gödel has shown that it is possible to use relativity to describe an universe where time travel is possible, then we can at least logically assume that a better, more complex description of our own universe (i.e. a more complex solution to Einstein’s equations which describe an universe that we can fully validate empirically) may also include the possibility of time travel. In other words: Gödel showed that time travel is not mathematically impossible using relativity to describe universes. What is left undone is to find a solution to Einstein’s equations describing not only our universe in a better, more accurate way, but which also includes time travel. Just because there are no feasible solutions right now, that doesn’t mean they don’t exist; it just means that Einstein’s equations have not been solved with the proper parameters. You might therefore ask why not more work is put in this. One stupid reason is that Gödel, who might have done exactly that just to annoy his fellow mathematicians and physicists, is already dead, and few like to continue his always disturbing work. But a better reason is simply that such a description of the universe might be unnecessarily complicated. The solutions we have for Einstein’s equations right now are so precise in describing our own universe, to an incredible accuracy, validated over and over again, that — according to Occam’s Razor — scientists prefer to use the simplest explanation of our universe which has the most explanatory power. Creating an even more complex explanation — one that takes time travel into account — and painfully solving every tiny little equation to show that it indeed ‘fits’ to our universe and includes the possibility of time travel is far too much work for little value — unless, of course, someone had devised a time travel machine, and needed the equations to understand what it could accomplish. So here is the state-of-the-art from a scientific perspective: we have validated Einstein’s equations over and over again, and the more we validate the equations that describe our universe, the more accurately this validation is — so we can say with a very high degree of confidence (in fact, relativity is one of the most proven theories in science, closely followed by quantum mechanics and evolution through natural selection) that we got the ‘right’ solution to the equations. Nevertheless, we cannot rule out the possibility of time travel, because we know that there are perfectly valid solutions to Einstein’s equations which, indeed, include time travel. So we cannot rule out the possibility that our own universe — described by a more complex solution to Einstein’s equations — might, indeed, also include time travel. This is what is generally meant when we casually said that ‘time travel can be shown to be consistent with Einstein’s general relativity’. It is indeed, even if we haven’t figured out how to reconcile Gödel’s solution with the current solutions describing our universe — mostly because that work is fruitless and uninteresting to most physicists, unless, of course, something dramatic changes.Now, just because this area of research is pretty much a dead end (in the sense that not enough resources are placed in figuring out something which might be useless, except from a purely mathematical perspective), this does not mean that nobody has given the concept some thought. And, of course, the problem of time paradoxes is also one of the many that has bothered several scientists. Stephen Hawking proposed what is known as the Chronology protection conjecture[2]which roughly states that although time travel might be allowed at submicroscopic scales (which we know to be possible), the laws of physics may be such that time travel is impossible at macroscopic scales. Such a statement is not unusual, because we’re aware at lots of things that work well at submicroscopic scales, described by quantum mechanics, but which simply don’t happen at the macroscopic level. I could go on and list a few tons of those, but since these are not directly relevant to this question, I leave it as an exercise to the reader :) Google for them for a bit, and you’ll quickly figure out for yourself how weird, strange, and counter-nature the submicroscopic level is, even though it is so accurately described by quantum mechanics. So Hawking thinks that the same applies to time travel. While this is merely a conjecture and not even a hypothesis (which could be empirically or mathematically proven and therefore become a theory or law), there are solid, mathematical arguments sustaining that conjecture. In general, therefore, it is expected that researchers in the field of time travel, the closer they come to a solution to Einstein’s equations which simultaneously describe the observed universe accurately (to the same degree we already have today) and explain how time travel could work in our universe and our timeline, then such a solution would also include ‘new’ laws of physics (not a new system of laws, but rather new laws that would emerge from Einstein’s equations naturally, and which we didn’t know about, even though they had always existed — we just hadn’t a mathematical description of them) which would prevent macroscopical time travel. Think of some new equations which would require a small, finite amount of energy for a particle to do time travel, but, as more and more particles are added to the system, that amount of required energy quickly surpasses the whole mass of the observable universe or becomes infinite; in other words, we might be able to send particles forwards and backwards in time, and perhaps by tapping the power of the Sun or of the whole Milky Way we might even send a few atoms back in time, but the equations would never allow us to send the tiniest bacteria across a ‘closed timelike curve’. This would not be the same thing as imagining some sort of anthropomorphic ‘agency’ which would ‘stop’ time travel (i.e. an inventor of a time travel machine breaking his creation due to regret at what it could accomplish), but rather the simple notion that the laws of physics simply don’t allow time travel to be accomplished at a macroscopic level in our universe (other universes, like the ones described by Gödel, would be different and allow time travel at the macroscopic levels — but such universes are not compatible with what we can observe of our universe, or, if they match a lot of characteristics, they tend to be inherently unstable and collapse of their own accord). Now, to prove that Hawking is right in his conjecture, we would need to develop a full theory of quantum gravity, and we haven’t that yet; even string theory, with all its faults and lack of completeness, tends to indicate that the conjecture would hold, but, again, string theory is still not a full theory that can be empirically validated — yet. Even if we assume that Hawking is a loony and that he doesn’t know what he’s talking about, there are at least two other, weaker explanations of why time travel hasn’t happened yet and why there was no need for an inventor of time travel to destroy his own machine. One is known as the Novikov self-consistency principle[3]which states that if we have an universe where time travel is possible (i.e. a particular solution of Einstein’s equations which precisely describe our universe and includes ‘closed timelike curves’, the ability to do time travel), then the probability of an time travelling event in the past to change our current timeline is zero. In other words, under Novikov’s principle, we could have macroscopic time travel of some sort, but if a time traveller would attempt to change irrevocably events in the past to affect the course of history in the future, then such attempts would never succeed (i.e. they would have a probability of zero success). In other words: we might be able to time travel to watch Jesus being crucified, and possibly, under Novikov’s explanation, perhaps the crucifixion is currently being watched by millions of time travelers, but all of them would have to be properly attired and speaking flawless Aramaic or Greek to be able even to converse with natives of that time and period — but they could never prevent the crucifixion from happening. If they tried to do that, their time travel would be abruptly cancelled — somehow, the machine providing the time travel would blow up from an energy surge or be destroyed by a singularity or something tragic like that. In essence, time travellers would be passive spectators, or at most innocent bystanders who would eventually be able to interact with the environment but have no way to affect the future. Now, Novikov’s principle might just seem to be an arbitrary rule, but it is actually grounded on some solid physics, and, indeed, a few followers of Novikov’s theories have shown that a time traveller ‘inside’ a ‘closed timelike curve’ would be limited in their actions; each action would trigger a certain amount of events, and there is a mathematical limit to how many events could be added until the ‘closed timelike curve’ collapses mathematically. I cannot pretend to understand what exactly this means, on the mathematical side of things, but it is interpreted as meaning that the more you try to change the past to affect the future, the more likely the ‘closed timelike curve’ generated by a time machine will collapse of its own accord. It’s not clear for a layperson how exactly human actions translate to complex mathematical descriptions of events — and those somehow are related to the energy necessary to maintain the ‘closed timelike curve’ — but I’m assuming that those who research these areas of physics know what they are doing :) Perhaps a similar concept which is more accessible to everyone is trying to accelerate a (macroscopic) mass to the speed of light. As we get faster and faster, our mass increases more and more (requiring more and more energy to sustain the acceleration), until it quickly becomes an exponential resulting in infinity: so, a body accelerated to lightspeed will have infinite mass and require infinite energy to continue its progression. It’s not like Einstein imagines a traffic cop raising a sign if you’re travelling too fast; it’s simply that the equations describing near-lightspeed acceleration will very quickly converge to infinity, rendering such accelerations impossible — and not because somehow there is something ‘magical’ in the ‘prohibition’ of going beyond lightspeed. I imagine that the same concept applies to time travellers using the Novikov principle: if you time travel just to observe past events and keep quiet about them, then you spend little energy, and the time travel machine will allow you to do that. As you start to interact with people and events in the past, in the attempt to change them and affect the future, then the time machine will require more and more energy to sustain the ‘closed timelike curve’ until it exponentially consumes energy reaching infinity at the exact moment where you are almost succeeding in killing your own grandfather; at that moment, the machine explodes and you’re back to where you started. Under Novikov’s principle, therefore, time travellers could exist, they could have perfectly working time machines, but, because they couldn’t affect the past, they would have no need of destroying their creations — thus providing an explanation of why we don’t have time travellers at all points of History attempting to change our timeline. We might also not be able to ‘see’ time travellers because they would have no choice but to interact with us in a manner that they would cause exactly zero interference with out timeline — in other words: the safest way to time travel would be to observe only, while if interaction was desired, such time travellers would need to look exactly like natives, talk like natives, dress like natives, pretend to be native; otherwise, if they start giving out clues that they come from the far future, their time machines would simply collapse before they had any chance to tell us anything. Pretty neat, huh? Novikov, of course, is not universally accepted, and many physicists have refuted him with several complex arguments; so we have no way of knowing how ‘right’ he is. There is another further alternative, which is to assume that the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics is true. In such a scenario, time travel would be done across alternative timelines; in other words, if you travelled to the past, you would shift to a different timeline, where you could not affect your present or future. You would affect that timeline’s future only. This would still allow time travel to do very interesting things — say, historic research, taking pictures of the crucifixion and bring them back, in full HDR — but it would make it impossible to ‘affect’ the past because we would simply be travelling to an alternate world, exactly like ours with the tiny difference that you could affect its future. The many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics solves a lot of problems (not only with time travel), but introduces also many of its own, and this is one reason why it’s also not universally accepted either. It cannot be shrugged off or discarded easily, of course, because it’s a mathematically plausible interpretation of quantum mechanics; it’s just not popular enough among physicists, since other interpretations provide even greater explanatory power, at least in areas which physicists are more interested in researching (time travel is not a popular field of study…). Last but not least, it has been shown that in ‘our’ universe (that is, the universe currently being described by a particular solution to Einstein’s equations), ‘solving’ the problem of faster-than-light travel will result in creating a time machine; in other words, the two problems are equivalent, if you discover one, you discover the other. Now, while time travel might not be a fundamental area of research (except perhaps for those who are more philosophically inclined), faster-than-light travel is crucial for interstellar exploration, and it has been given some considerable thought — and even some experimenting. Because going deeper in this subject means getting off topic, I will just give one very interesting example, the Alcubierre drive[4], which has also been nicknamed ‘warp drive’ (and yes, Alcubierre told William Shatner in an email that he was inspired by Star Trek). This intriguing device ‘cheats’ the lightspeed limit by subtly ‘warping’ (i.e. deforming) local spacetime, and sort of ‘riding the wave’ of that deformation, which in turn allows a spaceship to move at what would be perceived as faster-than-light travel from the perspective of an Earth observer. In reality, such a spaceship would technically be absolutely static and not move at all, when referencing its local spacetime frame. It’s just that spacetime would be pushed and pulled — deformed, warped — around it, so it would look like it’s moving from the perspective of an observer outside that frame. The passengers inside the spaceship would not feel any acceleration or any other force; and they would also not ‘suffer’ from any relativistic time paradoxes, i.e. time for them would pass exactly as time for an external observer. This neat trick of ‘deforming space’ to ‘violate’ the lightspeed limit is actually quite interesting, because in truth no laws of physics are being broken. The mathematical explanation is beyond me, of course, but at least I can point to one very complex aspect of Einstein’s general relativity, and that is that it applies to referential frames; there is an aspect of locality inherent in relativity, and it’s regarding to that ‘locality’ that things like the speed of light do apply. In other words: two frames might actually move faster than the speed of light when considering the speed that each of one us using relatively to the other, if there is no exchange of information between them. This is something even I have some difficulty of understanding, but it makes sense from the perspective of the Alcubierre drive: you’re shifting frames of reference around the universe, at speeds faster than light, but nobody is actually in touch with the spaceship while it’s inside the ‘warp bubble’. Light, when measured inside the spaceship, is faster than the spaceship itself, like it has to be, if we are maintaining general relativity. It’s just that bits of the universe, inside the ‘warp bubble’, are being shifted around. Of course, this neat trick is very cool but required, in theory, things like exotic matter and negative energy. This should place the Alcubierre drive into the realm of science fiction, but there are a few people (even at NASA) that think otherwise and devised a few experiments to shift some particles around using a modified Alcubierre drive. So far, the last experiment, done in 2012 or so, was pretty much inconclusive, and we have to assume that NASA gave up on that. Now, the interesting bit about the Alcubierre drive is that it provides faster-than-light travel without breaking any physical laws, nor requiring ‘infinite’ amounts of energy, and, most importantly, without creating any time paradoxes. It is therefore consistent with the conjectures and principles enumerated above, and contradicts the idea that faster-than-light travel implies the existence of time machines. Not so with the Alcubierre drive, because it’s a static device which is technically not moving — it’s space that is being warped ‘under’ it. Therefore, all usual issues affecting near-to-lightspeed travel do not apply to spaceships equipped with Alcubierre drives, and no time paradoxes emerge from travelling around the universe with a ‘warp drive’, although there are many other implications which might render the Alcubierre drive impossible (we’ll see about that!). So… to conclude… Time travel is possible, if you just have the right solution to Einstein’s general relativity equations. Some solutions, like the one from Gödel, admit time travel, but they do not describe our universe. We would need a different solution to Einstein’s equations, but that is just a question of applying some time to do that. Nothing in the theory prevents time travel; it’s just that the current solutions we have for Einstein’s equations and which we know to represent our universe with an incredible degree of accuracy do not include the possibility of ‘closed timelike curves’ which would allow time travel.If time travel is possible, and the Hawking conjecture holds, then time travel is only possible for submicroscopic particles, and we do not need to worry: there are no time travellers, existing time machines in the future will only be able to send particles back in time, and they will not need to destroy their creations.If time travel is possible, and Hawking was wrong, but Novikov is right, then we can construct time machines which would allow visitors from the future to observe and even interact with the past, but, at the moment they try to affect the future by changing events in the past, such time machines would collapse the ‘closed timelike curves’ due to fundamental laws of physics (i.e. affecting the past to change the future might require infinite energy). This would therefore mean that creators of time machines would not need to worry about accidentally changing the past, because that would be physically impossible to do. People would still be able to do time travel and enjoy themselves quite a lot, and perhaps this is happening now as we speak, but nothing that they are doing right now will affect either our past or our future, so we have nothing to worry about.If 2 and 3 are wrong, but the multiple-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics is right, then time travel would just place us in an alternative timeline. We would be able to explore it and affect its events as much as we wished — and that would possibly provide us with lots of insights about historical events — but we would not be affecting our own timeline, just an alternative timeline. Thus, no time travellers can come from the future to affect our timeline — they’re all happily exploring parallel timelines to ours and having fun murdering their own grandfathers, Hitler, Stalin, Donald Trump, etc. and see what happens. All that would be perfectly harmless towards our universe and timeline, which is not accessible in any case, so no time machine inventors need to worry about their machines.If we develop faster-than-light transportation, then it will very likely be of the kind suggested by Alcubierre, or a similar variation, where we are not really accelerating beyond the speed of light (and thus having the ability to time travel, according to an interpretation of general relativity…), but we would simply be compressing, deforming, warping space, which is theoretically possible (remember, any body of matter will deform spacetime due to the action of gravity) and feasible, without breaking any laws of physics, and, most importantly, not falling into any time paradoxes whatsoever, since devices similar to the description of the Alcubierre drive are technically static and therefore, not moving relatively to their frame of reference, thus not subject to any strange paradoxes.Whew. Ok. So this was perhaps not the most interesting answer, and certainly not the most creative one; but I hope to have given a glimpse on what is the current state-of-the-art of scientific thought regarding time travel, and I think we can remain optimistic for a while — time travellers will not be changing our past, and therefore we can sleep at ease during the night! PROLOGUE: TRAVEL BACK IN TIME IS NOT POSSIBLE. BUT WHAT IF IT IS? I do not believe time travel to the past is possible; having given the matter enough thought to become convinced that it is absurd to believe that anything ever escapes the present, and that the present’s continuous transformation into the future leaves nothing behind. There is nothing backwards in time to travel to. Running time measurement devices backwards does not affect the forward flow of time, it only operates to confuse our thinking. No evidence or logic suggests that time can ever flow backwards. I will below nevertheless attempt to analyze what time travel would mean to a traveler and to those existing when the traveler departs. THE NATURE OF SPACE-TIME PREVENTS CALCULATION OF A DESTINATION. Even if a way of moving the date and “time” of the present were invented, it remains impossible to calculate a specific destination before traveling. One’s location within the universe is constantly changing at huge speeds relative to other matter (the more distant the faster it recedes from us), and only the concurrent motion of our immediate environment masks this, just as the earth’s rotation is hidden from us because everything on its surface is rotating with us. When considering the spacial location changes of anything over time, give some thought to science’s discoveries about the expanding universe and what it means on the galactic scale over time; coupled with the motions of galaxies, stars, planets and gases throughout the universe dancing in space under the force of gravity, black energy, photons, electro magnetism and the atomic forces; stirred further by space-time distortion generated by innumerable black holes. How can position in the universe at a past time be calculated to determine a destination when time traveling? That is, assuming it were possible at all to treat the past as if it were a location. No fixed references to past locations of the original environment are determinable. The time traveler can never determine where the intended arrival point is to be, even if somehow the when could be determined. This is the reality of space-time in our universe. This is another problem I will ignore below in my hypothetical analysis. WHAT EFFECT WOULD TRAVEL TO THE PAST HAVE ON THE PRESENT? Despite my disbelief, it is a sobering exercise to imagine trips into the past and such voyages’ effects on the flow of events which culminated in the present existing as the voyagers begin time travel. As a mental game, the rules as to how it would confuse the pre-existing time line of events can be puzzled out, with many things proposed ruled impossible contrary to careless assumptions. First, any change in the flow of events resulting from the backwards time travel must result in unending changes in events, like circles of dominoes falling outward. This happens not only on the scale humans observe, but on all scales of existence down to and even below the scale of quantum physics and multi-dimensional strings of energy. Ever widening sub-atomic effects extend into multiple dimensions, altering events whose very existence is beyond our human capacity to detect or even imagine. The time traveler’s “destination in time” [ignoring for simpler analysis the problem of location] will be a “present” which for an infinitesimally small point matches a moment of the past of the universe the traveler started from. TIME TRAVEL DESTROYS THE TRAVELER’S PREVIOUS REALITY. Thereafter the changes begin. There will never be a way for the destination’s forward moving present to become the same as the time track taken by the universe from which the time traveler left. The old “present” from which the trip commenced will never exist. The mental states, memories, form of being, and many or all other qualities of the humans existing when the traveler left never form. The extent of the changes will of course depend, to a theoretical (but impossibly “outside the universe”) observer, on the time distance traveled, since a nanosecond of travel leaves a far smaller footprint than a hundred years of travel due to the quantity of time available for the ripples of change to spread. However big the change, the change will be absolute and obliterate the “old” present, which never occurs, and a new present instantly comes into being with a time line leading to different presents through cause and effect on every scale. Running time measurement devices backwards does not affect the forward flow of time, it only operates to confuse our thinking. No evidence or logic suggests that time can ever flow backwards. TIME TRAVEL IS UNDETECTABLE TO ANYONE EXCEPT THE TRAVELER. There will be no “jump/slip” or trace of memory of never to occur events because those former future humans never existed at all, and never will exist (at least as they “were.”). The former “present” is destroyed instantly after the Traveler’s arrival in the past, when the timeline of cause and effect is changed. If time travel, contrary to my intuitive belief, is a real possibility, it is undetectable to all other as they are at all times in the present of the only time of the universe (the present) which has at such moment ever existed. Alternate futures have no existence once modified. TIME TRAVEL WILL NOT CAUSE ANY PARADOX OF CAUSE AND EFFECT. Here’s why seems an apparent paradox (the traveler’s origin) is avoided. Time travelers themselves, after arrival, are no longer from a future that ever existed. It will seem like they came from a real place to theTravelers, assuming they are alive and conscious throughout their experience before during and after the travel. Nevertheless, when arriving in the past (the new present), a time traveler will have just popped into existence from nowhere, because the time left never will exist. They will be able to affect the flow of events upon arrival, in fact unable not to affect how events occur. But they are now constrained in the present they find themselves, with nothing to return to. As their new present moves into its future, they will be living in a new place in which time goes forward as it always does. The further back they went, the more events in the destination will vary as time advances, and they will be interacting with their present without any stake in modifying the former reality they left. Surprises will multiply for them when expectations of identical timeline are met with unanticipated changes, and with enough distance traveled, the travelers’ hopes to control the future will be dashed. RESULTS FROM TIME TRAVEL ARE UNCONTROLLABLE. So what would the point of intentional time travel be? Even were profit realized from some potential accurate predictions, the future will remain uncertain in the new present, the same insecurities and risks we must accept as part of our present daily lives would be part of the traveler’s life, and the moment of death cannot be known. Might just as well stay in the present, from an existential perspective. Not to mention homesickness for a future and people that will never be. There would be a total failure of evidence supporting any traveler’s claim of travel. Time travel would never be established to have occurred by those in the present where the traveler arrived, so such a claim would be unlikely to ever be accepted. Claims of travel would likely be treated as insanity or worse. NO PROGRAM OR RESEARCH EFFORT TO TRAVEL IN TIME DESERVES OUR SUPPORT. Those contemplating time travel may wish to turn attention to other problems, after reflection of the points raised above. Socially, no reason to support such an effort seems to merit support, considering one result of such travel is destruction of the reality of the current present time. One would hope that were the consequences of time travel fully considered, no sane person would attempt to construct such a machine. That still leaves room to fear acts by the insane. CONCLUSION, AND ULTIMATE ANSWER TO QUESTION. It is likely that if I am wrong about the possibility of building a time machine, it is very likely such invention has been deliberately destroyed by its maker. The unanswered point of speculation remains. Was it used first? We will never know.
